Package org.hs.jfc

This package contains alternatives to some of the cumbersome facilities of the JFC.

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
HotComponent Welcome to HotComponent, a new alternative to drag-and-drop that is substantially less processor intensive, allows free use of the mouse during the object association process, and offers a much more concise and reliable API.
 

Class Summary
CursorCenter The CursorCenter creates a cache of colorizable java.awt.Cursor templates.
CursorCenter.Descriptor Describes a colorizable java.awt.Cursor with its image file (which must be in standard .gif format: funny compressions don't work), the color of the transparent regions, and the color of the colorizable regions.
FormLayout A layout manager modeled after the HTML tag.
FormPanel This convenient class is just a JPanel with FormLayout as its default layout manager.
HotComponent.Arbiter The Arbiter pays a visit to your component upon registration with the HotStation, in the callback method register(Arbiter).
HotComponent.Constraints  
HotComponent.HotCollection The HotCollection is actually a collection wrapper that provides a catalog of the types contained in the wrapped collection.
HotStation The HotStation facilitates the various processes of HotComponent data exchange.
hVector This java.util.Vector wrapper supports earlier versions of the JDK.
 

Package org.hs.jfc Description

This package contains alternatives to some of the cumbersome facilities of the JFC. HotComponent serves the same purpose as drag and drop, but is substantially less processor intensive, easier to code, and allows the user to use their mouse buttons while choosing and navigating to the drop location. FormLayout organizes standard input components into rows and columns in a predictable, intuitive, and easily coded manner. The package is available free for your use, modification, and redistribution, though it remains under the copyright of HawkinsSoftware (1999,2003).
